moves.1. d4 Nf6: Another Remohgramps game, this one is quick and brutal. Not much to see here (just annotating it because I annotate all my games). We were both playing fast, the game ended in just a few hours while we were both playing frequenly in multiple other games as well - a sure recipe for disaster. White's d4 meets black's Indian System.
moves.3. Nh3 d5: Claiming a slice of the center with a secondary threat.
moves.4. Nc3 Bxh3: Getting right into it. White needs to be careful here.
moves.5. gxh3 Nxg5: Oops. 5. gxh3? was a blunder and it cost white a piece. Better was 5. Nxe4.
moves.6. Qd2 e6: Defending the knight and the pawn.
moves.7. h4 Ne4: 7. ... Nh4 is a bit strange, but 6. ... e6 left the knight only this one move to escape white's pawn on h4.
moves.8. Nxe4 dxe4: Doubled pawns. Well, at least white has some doubled pawns too...
moves.10. d5 e5: Getting a little scary. If 10. ... Qxf2, then 11. dxe6 opens the d-file for white to get a back-rank checkmate with 12. Qd8#. Black could prevent it, but now that the threat is on the board, I prefer simply to advance with 10. ... e5 and not have to worry about it.
moves.12. Bb5+ Nd7 13. Bxd7+ Kxd7: Well, so much for castling. But things are going well, so a central king isn't too much of a burden at the moment.
moves.14. Qb4 Bxb4: Oops again. 14. ... Qb4?? was truly a decisive blunder. Already down a piece and a pawn, white cannot afford the outright loss of his queen and resigns on the spot. A bit anticlimactic after my near-death experience against the same opponent in our last game (refer to the Giving Him a Little Rope #2 annotation).
